content:
This is quite a trap for Reverse...
The first four or so test cases all work perfectly without any rounding, so it seems like it will be that way for all of them, but then you suddenly have answers that don't work.

Luckily I waited to see all test cases before hitting submit, but it's quite unexpected to have to do rounding in a reverse clash for solving such equations, which you assume to be perfect integer solutions.

⚠️ Modified the contribution: 

- Added a test case for when N = 0 (it used to be hidden in validators only)
- Added a test case to make sure the number must be rounded UP.
Can someone from CG remove this "thing" PLEASE
The test and validations are incorrect. This needs to be fixed.

This one is a shame. 
How someone can even thing about validate such a thing. The sols are not correct. An equation is an equation. If one want some "approximation" do not use = symbol.
Since people are approving this, I modified the last validator according to my other comment below, so 100% in tests with rounding will give 100% in validators too.
Last two tests and validations are incorrect.
Thanks, I'm looking into the solution code now to find out why this has occurred.

In fact, using round (in python3) passes all test cases but not the validator 5. The real answer being 2.5, python3's round uses statistician's rounding and returns 2 because 2 is an even digit followed by only the digit 5. 
2.5000001 would be rounded to 3 (obviously) and 1.5 is rounded to 2 because 1 is odd (so test 6 passes). 
Suggestion : avoid 2 as coefficient for N (except for integer solutions)
Done. No more ".5".
I see what I've done now, the solution isn't incorrect. N should be rounded up so it is in fact correct.
Oh, I see, it could be a tricky one in the reverse mode
Yeah, should I remove those?
I guess, we could try to leave, let's see what another reviewers think.
Alright.
I like it, however this is not a problem I want to face!
Do you have any suggestions so that I could make the puzzle easier?

You could do it so that the answer is at 'a/b' form, instead of integer or float - with the lowest a and b possible. Adds a bit of challenge but clears things up. Regarding the difficulty, some difficult challenges once in a while are needed. It's ideal for a 15 min reverse clash. Also, in case you think it will not harm the challenge, adding 'Solution:' to the output would make it "easier" from the point that it would be faster to figure out what is needed.

The fact it's a reverse is not the big difficulty here.  I think it's pretty obvious we have to solve for N.  The only major problem I see with the 2 lasts tests/validator is that for the 2 tests, rounding to the nearest integer or rounding up gives the same result.  But for the last validator, it doesn't.  So people rounding to the nearest integer will have 100% in tests but will fail the last validator.
Also, I would include tests where the first number has more than one digit, and the last number more than 2, just to reflect the kind of numbers we have in the validators.
